newsitem.title: JAPAN: BOJ says baht move increases scope for cooperation.
newsitem.headline: BOJ says baht move increases scope for cooperation.

text.p: The flotation of the Thai baht increases the scope for cooperation among central banks, a senior official of the Bank of Japan (BOJ) told Reuters Financial Television on Wednesday.
The official added that while the BOJ was informed of Thailand's surprise decision to shift from a pegged currency to a "managed float", Thai authorities did not ask for assistance.

"I am sure the Thai authorities had a very difficult time deciding to change their system, but in this global market it is almost impossible to try to protect a certain exchange rate against all odds. In that sense the decision was inevitable," the official said.
"I think the decision was extremely good for its timing, and the fact it will allow flexible responses based on market conditions," he added.
The official dismissed Wednesday's speculative buying of the yen as a safe-haven currency.
"The move was not great, it was really just an excuse to buy the yen," he said.
But the de facto baht devaluation will make it more difficult for Thailand to repay its external debts, of which yen-denominated loans total 12.935 trillion yen.
The BOJ official said that because of this, Japan will continue to consider offering soft loans to Thailand.
